column1: Okha (Russian: Оха́) is a town and the administrative center of Okhinsky District of Sakhalin Oblast
column3: located on the east coast of the far north of Sakhalin island
column4: approximately 850 kilometers (530 mi) north of Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk
column5: near the shoreline of the Sea of Okhotsk. Population: 23

column1: It was founded shortly after the discovery of petroleum in the area in 1880
column2: initially under the name Okhe. The name is derived from an Ainu word meaning Bad Water. Industrial exploitation of the petroleum reserves began in 1923
column3: during the Japanese occupation of Sakhalin from 1920-1925. Town status was granted to it in 1938.The town suffered significant damage in the 1995 Neftegorsk earthquake that occurred on May 28
column4: and was used as pivotal base for rescuers deployed to Neftegorsk
column5: which was destroyed to the extent that it was not rebuilt. A number of survivors of Neftegorsk were later transferred to Okha. Another smaller earthquake hit the town on May 10
column7: but there were no fatalities or significant damage.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Okha serves as the administrative center of Okhinsky District and is subordinated to it. As a municipal division
column3: the town of Okha and ten rural localities of Okhinsky District are incorporated as Okhinsky Urban Okrug.

column2: along with the oblast's administrative center Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk
column3: is the center of Sakhalin's petroleum industry. An oil pipeline and gas main runs from Okha to Komsomolsk-on-Amur on the Russian mainland. A number of oil wells exist in close proximity to the town
column4: mainly controlled by the company Rosneft.
